question_details.query: Which interventions can increase invertebrate abundance on subtidal artificial structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
- Creating hole habitats (>50 mm) increased the abundance of brown crabs on and around structures in one study, while another study reported mixed effects on invertebrate abundances when holes were implemented alongside pits, grooves and environmentally-sensitive material [3434].
- Constructing artificial reefs with specific materials/designs increased some invertebrates: breakwaters made of bags of oyster shells recruited more oysters and ribbed mussels than “ReefBall” breakwaters, and in one case “sea-friendly” concrete pyramid reefs had higher overall abundance than plinth‑pole structures after three years [2259].
- Other surface‑complexity interventions showed mixed effects on invertebrate abundance depending on species, site or surface orientation: creating grooves (1–50 mm) [3448], pits (1–50 mm) [3455], combined grooves and small protrusions/ridges/ledges (1–50 mm) [3452], textured surfaces (≤1 mm) [3449], and adding short (1–50 mm) [3450] or long (>50 mm) [3451] flexible habitats.
summary_statements: Creating hole habitats larger than 50 mm increased the abundance of brown crabs on and around structures.
Implementing holes alongside pits, grooves, and environmentally-sensitive material had mixed effects on invertebrate abundances.
Breakwaters made of bags of oyster shells recruited more oysters and ribbed mussels than “ReefBall” breakwaters.
“Sea-friendly” concrete pyramid reefs had a higher overall invertebrate abundance than plinth-pole structures after three years.
Certain surface-complexity interventions showed mixed effects on invertebrate abundance depending on the species, site, or surface orientation.
Creating grooves between 1 and 50 mm had mixed effects on invertebrate abundance.
Creating pits between 1 and 50 mm had mixed effects on invertebrate abundance.
Creating combined grooves and small protrusions, ridges, or ledges between 1 and 50 mm had mixed effects on invertebrate abundance.
Creating textured surfaces of 1 mm or less had mixed effects on invertebrate abundance.
Adding short flexible habitats between 1 and 50 mm had mixed effects on invertebrate abundance.
Adding long flexible habitats larger than 50 mm had mixed effects on invertebrate abundance.

question_details.query: What are the benefits of creating rock pools on intertidal artificial structures for overall species richness?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across 12 replicated, controlled studies, rock pools created on intertidal artificial structures supported higher combined macroalgae, invertebrate and/or fish species richness and/or diversity than structure surfaces without pools in nine studies, while three reported similar richness; one study also found created pools had similar combined richness to natural rock pools, and another reported lower richness for combined mobile invertebrates and fishes in created pools [3476]. Several moderators were reported: shore level did not affect species richness in some studies, pool depth often had no effect, tilted pools had higher richness than horizontal ones, and adding short flexible habitats had mixed effects depending on species group and site [3476]. A before-and-after study reported that creating pools alongside reducing structure slope increased combined macroalgae, invertebrate and fish species richness on the structure [3476]. One study reported that creating rock pools did not increase fish species richness on and around the structure [3476].
summary_statements: In nine of twelve replicated, controlled studies, rock pools created on intertidal artificial structures supported higher combined macroalgae, invertebrate, and/or fish species richness than structure surfaces without pools.
Three of twelve replicated, controlled studies reported that created rock pools had similar species richness to structure surfaces without pools.
One study found that created rock pools had a combined richness similar to that of natural rock pools.
One study reported lower richness for combined mobile invertebrates and fishes in created pools compared to natural pools.
Some studies reported that shore level did not affect species richness in created rock pools.
The depth of created rock pools often had no effect on species richness.
Tilted created rock pools had higher species richness than horizontal ones.
Adding short flexible habitats to created rock pools had mixed effects on species richness, depending on the species group and site.
A before-and-after study reported that creating pools on a structure while also reducing the structure's slope increased the combined species richness of macroalgae, invertebrates, and fish.
One study reported that creating rock pools did not increase the species richness of fish on and around the structure.

question_details.query: What are the general effects on biodiversity of creating linear depressions or elevations on intertidal artificial structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across studies of linear depressions (grooves) and elevations (ridges/ledges) on intertidal artificial structures, reported effects on biodiversity were mixed: creating large ledges or ridges (>50 mm) sometimes increased invertebrate (e.g., mussels or limpets) abundance but not barnacles, and increased rockweed abundance and combined macroalgae–microalgae–invertebrate abundance and diversity in some cases, while combined macroalgae–invertebrate richness did not always increase; juvenile salmon abundance did not increase but feeding activity increased (3465). Creating small groove habitats (1–50 mm) sometimes increased combined macroalgae and invertebrate richness/diversity and abundance, and altered or supported distinct communities and fish communities (often alongside pits), but multiple studies reported no increases in richness or abundance for macroalgae or invertebrates, and fish richness/abundance responses ranged from increases (with pits) to no change; grooves often supported species absent from ungrooved surfaces and were used by mussels and periwinkles (3473). Creating combinations of grooves with small protrusions/ridges/ledges (1–50 mm) often altered community composition and sometimes increased combined macroalgae–invertebrate richness/diversity and abundance, though many studies found mixed or no effects depending on groove/ridge size, arrangement, shore level, covers, or site; invertebrate abundances showed mixed responses with some increases (e.g., oysters) and fish abundances generally did not increase, while fish feeding or interaction behavior sometimes changed (3474).
summary_statements: Across studies, the reported effects on biodiversity from creating linear depressions or elevations on intertidal artificial structures were mixed.
Creating large ledges or ridges greater than 50 mm sometimes increased the abundance of invertebrates like mussels or limpets.
The creation of large ledges or ridges did not increase barnacle abundance.
The creation of large ledges or ridges sometimes increased rockweed abundance.
In some cases, creating large ledges or ridges increased the combined abundance and diversity of macroalgae, microalgae, and invertebrates.
The combined richness of macroalgae and invertebrates did not always increase with the creation of large ledges or ridges.
The abundance of juvenile salmon did not increase with the creation of large ledges or ridges.
The feeding activity of juvenile salmon did increase with the creation of large ledges or ridges.
Creating small groove habitats between 1 and 50 mm sometimes increased the combined richness, diversity, and abundance of macroalgae and invertebrates.
Creating small groove habitats sometimes altered or supported distinct communities, including fish communities.
Multiple studies reported no increases in the richness or abundance of macroalgae or invertebrates from the creation of small grooves.
The responses of fish richness and abundance to small grooves ranged from increases to no change.
Grooves often supported species that were absent from ungrooved surfaces.
Grooves were used by mussels and periwinkles.
Creating combinations of grooves with small protrusions, ridges, or ledges often altered community composition.
Creating combinations of grooves with small protrusions, ridges, or ledges sometimes increased the combined richness, diversity, and abundance of macroalgae and invertebrates.
Many studies found that combinations of grooves and ridges had mixed or no effects, depending on factors like size, arrangement, shore level, covers, or site.
Invertebrate abundances showed mixed responses to combinations of grooves and ridges, with some increases for species such as oysters.
Fish abundances generally did not increase with the creation of combinations of grooves and small protrusions, ridges, or ledges.
The feeding or interaction behavior of fish sometimes changed due to the creation of combinations of grooves and small protrusions, ridges, or ledges.

question_details.query: Which interventions are most consistently effective at altering the overall community composition on subtidal artificial structures?
For intertidal artificial structures in Australia, which habitat modifications have shown mixed or neutral results for fish abundance?
Which interventions have been shown to benefit fish populations on subtidal artificial structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Creating hole, groove and pit habitats (often implemented together and sometimes with environmentally-sensitive materials) supported fish species that were absent from similar structures without these added features, and had mixed effects on fish abundances depending on species group [3434; 3448; 3455]. Creating long flexible habitats supported fish species that were absent from structures without flexible habitats, and had mixed effects on fish abundance and fish species richness depending on context; seahorses used these flexible habitats [3451]. Creating short flexible habitats had mixed effects on seahorse abundance around structures, varying by survey week [3450].
summary_statements: Creating hole, groove, and pit habitats supported fish species that were absent from similar structures without these added features.
Creating hole, groove, and pit habitats had mixed effects on fish abundances depending on the species group.
Creating long flexible habitats supported fish species that were absent from structures without flexible habitats.
Creating long flexible habitats had mixed effects on fish abundance and fish species richness depending on context.
Seahorses used long flexible habitats.
Creating short flexible habitats had mixed effects on seahorse abundance around structures, with the effect varying by survey week.

question_details.query: What conservation actions for artificial structures have been studied in estuaries in Australia, and what were the outcomes?

summary_details.relevant_summary: In estuaries in southeast Australia, studies on intertidal structures reported that reducing structure slope (often alongside adding rock pools) increased combined macroalgae, invertebrate and fish species richness, but did not increase macroalgal, oyster or mobile invertebrate abundance [3461]. Transplanting or seeding biota onto intertidal structures (including oysters and coralline algae) supported species otherwise absent and had mixed effects on combined richness/diversity and invertebrate abundance, while generally not increasing fish richness or abundance; mobile invertebrate richness increased in one Australian study [3472]. Creating short flexible habitats (1–50 mm) on intertidal structures altered combined macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrate community composition, decreased combined species richness at low tide, and showed mixed effects on macroalgal and invertebrate abundances; fish richness and abundance at high tide did not increase [3459]. Creating pit habitats (1–50 mm) on intertidal structures altered community composition in some studies, sometimes supported species absent from flat surfaces, and showed mixed effects on combined richness and invertebrate abundances across sites and designs, including in Australian estuaries [3475]. Creating hole habitats (>50 mm) on intertidal structures, often alongside other features, increased combined macroalgae and invertebrate richness/diversity, supported species absent from flat surfaces, and did not consistently increase macroalgal or invertebrate abundance; added holes and pools were used by sea slugs, urchins and octopuses in Australia [3467]. Using environmentally‑sensitive materials on intertidal structures (e.g., sandstone vs basalt, modified concretes, ECOncrete with grooves/ledges/holes) sometimes altered community composition and increased richness/diversity and overall cover, but effects on algal and invertebrate abundances were mixed across materials and sites, including an Australian estuary [3469]. On subtidal structures in Australian estuaries, creating long flexible habitats (>50 mm) supported species absent from bare surfaces and showed mixed effects on fish richness and on mobile and non‑mobile invertebrate abundances [3451]. Creating short flexible habitats (1–50 mm) on subtidal structures produced mixed effects on invertebrate community composition and abundances, and mixed effects on seahorse abundance, with no increase in invertebrate richness in a paired study [3450]. Transplanting or seeding onto subtidal structures included an Australian study where transplanted sea urchins reduced the cover of a non‑native sea mat on kelps; transplanted urchins survived [3471]. Using environmentally‑sensitive materials on subtidal structures (e.g., quarried rock, shell‑concrete, ECOncrete with added texture/holes/grooves/pits) sometimes altered community composition and increased richness/diversity, with mixed effects on macroalgal and invertebrate abundances across materials and locations that included Australian estuaries [3470].
summary_statements: In estuaries in southeast Australia, studies on intertidal structures reported that reducing the structure's slope increased combined macroalgae, invertebrate and fish species richness.
Reducing the slope of intertidal structures in southeast Australian estuaries did not increase macroalgal, oyster or mobile invertebrate abundance.
Transplanting or seeding biota like oysters and coralline algae onto intertidal structures supported species that were otherwise absent.
Transplanting or seeding biota onto intertidal structures had mixed effects on combined richness/diversity and invertebrate abundance.
Transplanting or seeding biota onto intertidal structures generally did not increase fish richness or abundance.
Mobile invertebrate richness increased in one Australian study where biota was transplanted or seeded onto intertidal structures.
Creating short flexible habitats on intertidal structures altered the combined community composition of macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrates.
Creating short flexible habitats on intertidal structures decreased combined species richness at low tide.
Creating short flexible habitats on intertidal structures showed mixed effects on macroalgal and invertebrate abundances.
Fish richness and abundance at high tide did not increase when short flexible habitats were created on intertidal structures.
Creating pit habitats on intertidal structures altered community composition in some studies, including in Australian estuaries.
Creating pit habitats on intertidal structures sometimes supported species that were absent from flat surfaces.
Creating pit habitats on intertidal structures showed mixed effects on combined richness and invertebrate abundances across sites and designs.
Creating hole habitats on intertidal structures, often alongside other features, increased combined macroalgae and invertebrate richness/diversity.
Creating hole habitats on intertidal structures supported species that were absent from flat surfaces.
Creating hole habitats on intertidal structures did not consistently increase macroalgal or invertebrate abundance.
In Australia, added holes and pools on intertidal structures were used by sea slugs, urchins and octopuses.
Using environmentally-sensitive materials on intertidal structures sometimes altered community composition and increased richness/diversity and overall cover.
The effects of using environmentally-sensitive materials on intertidal structures on algal and invertebrate abundances were mixed across materials and sites, including an Australian estuary.
On subtidal structures in Australian estuaries, creating long flexible habitats supported species that were absent from bare surfaces.
Creating long flexible habitats on subtidal structures in Australian estuaries showed mixed effects on fish richness and on mobile and non-mobile invertebrate abundances.
Creating short flexible habitats on subtidal structures produced mixed effects on invertebrate community composition and abundances.
Creating short flexible habitats on subtidal structures produced mixed effects on seahorse abundance.
In a paired study, creating short flexible habitats on subtidal structures caused no increase in invertebrate richness.
In an Australian study, transplanted sea urchins on subtidal structures reduced the cover of a non-native sea mat on kelps.
In an Australian study involving transplanting organisms onto subtidal structures, the transplanted urchins survived.
Using environmentally-sensitive materials on subtidal structures sometimes altered community composition and increased richness/diversity in locations that included Australian estuaries.
Using environmentally-sensitive materials on subtidal structures resulted in mixed effects on macroalgal and invertebrate abundances across materials and locations, including Australian estuaries.

question_details.query: What are the general effects of creating linear habitat features, such as grooves, ridges or ledges, on intertidal artificial structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across multiple studies, adding linear habitat features to intertidal artificial structures produced mixed but often positive changes to community composition and biodiversity. Groove habitats and small ridges/ledges sometimes altered macroalgae and invertebrate community composition, and in several cases supported species absent from unmodified surfaces [3474, 3473]. Species richness/diversity often increased with grooves and small ridges/ledges, though effects were mixed and context‑dependent; grooves frequently supported higher richness than adjacent small ridges/ledges [3474, 3464, 3473]. Large ledges, when added alongside grooves and small protrusions, increased combined macroalgae, microalgae and invertebrate diversity and abundance, and increased rockweed abundance; large ridges did not consistently raise richness [3465]. Invertebrate abundances showed mixed responses overall, with some increases for oysters and mussels in certain designs, but not for barnacles or mobile invertebrates in others; grooves often matched or exceeded small ledges for mobile invertebrates and oysters [3474, 3465, 3473, 3464]. Fish richness and abundance typically did not increase with grooves or small ledges, although responses varied by site; behavioral changes were observed, including more benthic interaction near small ledges and increased juvenile salmon feeding where large ledges and grooves were installed [3474, 3473, 3465].
summary_statements: Adding linear habitat features to intertidal artificial structures produced mixed but often positive changes to community composition and biodiversity.
Groove habitats and small ridges/ledges sometimes altered macroalgae and invertebrate community composition.
Groove habitats and small ridges/ledges in several cases supported species absent from unmodified surfaces.
Species richness and diversity often increased with the addition of grooves and small ridges/ledges.
The effects of grooves and small ridges/ledges on species richness and diversity were mixed and context-dependent.
Grooves frequently supported higher species richness than adjacent small ridges/ledges.
Large ledges added alongside grooves and small protrusions increased combined macroalgae, microalgae and invertebrate diversity and abundance.
Large ledges added alongside grooves and small protrusions increased rockweed abundance.
Large ridges did not consistently raise species richness.
Invertebrate abundances showed mixed responses overall to the addition of linear habitat features.
The abundance of oysters and mussels increased in certain designs of linear habitat features.
The abundance of barnacles or mobile invertebrates did not increase in other designs of linear habitat features.
Grooves often supported abundances of mobile invertebrates and oysters that matched or exceeded those on small ledges.
Fish richness and abundance typically did not increase with the addition of grooves or small ledges.
Fish responses to the addition of grooves or small ledges varied by site.
Behavioral changes in fish were observed, including more benthic interaction near small ledges.
Juvenile salmon feeding increased where large ledges and grooves were installed.

question_details.query: Which habitat creation methods appear most consistently effective at increasing overall species richness on subtidal artificial structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence on subtidal artificial structures reports that creating hole habitats (>50 mm) increased combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness and/or diversity in two of three replicated, controlled studies, while one study found no increase for combined mobile invertebrate and fish richness or diversity (3434). Creating grooves and small protrusions or ledges (1–50 mm) increased combined macroalgae and invertebrate richness and diversity in one of two replicated, randomized, controlled studies, while the other reported no increase in diversity and mixed effects on richness depending on surface orientation (3452). Creating pit habitats (1–50 mm) increased combined macroalgae and invertebrate species diversity in one replicated, controlled study (3455). For creating natural rocky reef topography, the available study reported no increase in juvenile canopy macroalgal abundance and reported no richness outcomes (3446). No studies were found evaluating effects on biodiversity for creating large ridges or ledges (>50 mm), small ridges or ledges (1–50 mm), or crevice habitats (>50 mm) on subtidal structures (3445; 3444; 3454).
summary_statements: Creating hole habitats larger than 50 mm on subtidal artificial structures increased combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness or diversity in two of three replicated, controlled studies.
One study on creating hole habitats on subtidal artificial structures found no increase for combined mobile invertebrate and fish richness or diversity.

Creating grooves and small protrusions or ledges between 1 and 50 mm on subtidal artificial structures increased combined macroalgae and invertebrate richness and diversity in one of two replicated, randomized, controlled studies.
One study on creating grooves and small protrusions or ledges on subtidal artificial structures reported no increase in diversity and mixed effects on richness depending on surface orientation.
Creating pit habitats between 1 and 50 mm on subtidal artificial structures increased combined macroalgae and invertebrate species diversity in one replicated, controlled study.
The available study on creating natural rocky reef topography on subtidal artificial structures reported no increase in juvenile canopy macroalgal abundance.
The available study on creating natural rocky reef topography on subtidal artificial structures reported no richness outcomes.
No studies were found evaluating effects on biodiversity from creating large ridges or ledges larger than 50 mm on subtidal structures.
No studies were found evaluating effects on biodiversity from creating small ridges or ledges between 1 and 50 mm on subtidal structures.
No studies were found evaluating effects on biodiversity from creating crevice habitats larger than 50 mm on subtidal structures.

question_details.query: What is the evidence for enhancing biodiversity on subtidal artificial structures by creating crevices, protrusions, ridges, ledges, or by reducing their slope?
Which habitat creation methods are most consistently effective at altering the overall community composition on intertidal artificial structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence on overall community composition shows: Creating pit habitats (1–50 mm) altered the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition in four of six replicated, controlled studies; one study found no effect, and one reported mixed effects when combined with other habitats; several studies also reported pits supported species absent from flat surfaces [3475]. Creating grooves and small protrusions/ridges/ledges (1–50 mm) altered community composition in three of five replicated, randomized, controlled studies; two studies found mixed effects; multiple studies also reported grooves/ridges supported species absent from flat surfaces [3474]. Creating rock pools frequently resulted in pools supporting species absent from flat surfaces in many studies, and at least one study reported pools supported different combined macroalgae and invertebrate communities than surfaces without pools; effects sometimes varied with pool design and site [3476]. Creating groove habitats (1–50 mm) did not alter community composition in two of three replicated, controlled studies, while one study found alteration; some studies noted grooves supported species absent from flat surfaces [3473]. Creating small protrusions (1–50 mm) did not alter community composition in one study; a study combining protrusions with grooves/ridges/pits found mixed effects depending on design and site [3462]. Creating short flexible habitats (1–50 mm) altered the combined macroalgae and non‑mobile invertebrate community composition in one replicated, randomized, controlled study, with mixed effects for mobile invertebrates and fishes [3459]. Creating large protrusions (>50 mm) led one study to report different community composition between angled vs horizontal protrusions and that protrusions supported species absent from flat surfaces [3463]. Creating small adjoining cavities or ‘swimthrough’ habitats (≤100 mm) did not alter the mobile invertebrate community composition in one replicated, controlled study [3468]. Using environmentally‑sensitive material altered community composition in two of four replicated, controlled studies; others found no effect or mixed effects depending on material and site [3469].
summary_statements: Creating pit habitats (1–50 mm) altered the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition in four of six replicated, controlled studies.
One study found that creating pit habitats had no effect on community composition.
One study reported mixed effects on community composition when pit habitats were combined with other habitats.
Several studies reported that pit habitats supported species that were absent from flat surfaces.
Creating grooves and small protrusions, ridges, or ledges (1–50 mm) altered community composition in three of five replicated, randomized, controlled studies.
Two studies found that creating grooves and small protrusions, ridges, or ledges had mixed effects on community composition.
Multiple studies reported that grooves or ridges supported species absent from flat surfaces.
Creating rock pools frequently resulted in the pools supporting species absent from flat surfaces in many studies.
At least one study reported that rock pools supported different combined macroalgae and invertebrate communities than surfaces without pools.
The effects of creating rock pools sometimes varied with pool design and site.
Creating groove habitats (1–50 mm) did not alter community composition in two of three replicated, controlled studies.
One study found that creating groove habitats did alter community composition.
Some studies noted that groove habitats supported species absent from flat surfaces.
Creating small protrusions (1–50 mm) did not alter community composition in one study.
A study combining protrusions with grooves, ridges, or pits found mixed effects on community composition depending on the design and site.
Creating short flexible habitats (1–50 mm) altered the combined macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrate community composition in one replicated, randomized, controlled study.
Creating short flexible habitats had mixed effects for mobile invertebrates and fishes in one study.
One study on large protrusions (>50 mm) reported a different community composition between angled versus horizontal protrusions.
The study on large protrusions also reported that the protrusions supported species absent from flat surfaces.
Creating small adjoining cavities or ‘swimthrough’ habitats (≤100 mm) did not alter the mobile invertebrate community composition in one replicated, controlled study.
Using environmentally-sensitive material altered community composition in two of four replicated, controlled studies.
Other studies found that using environmentally-sensitive material had no effect or mixed effects on community composition, depending on the material and site.

question_details.query: What are the potential negative impacts or limitations of adding topographical complexity to enhance biodiversity on intertidal artificial structures?
Besides choosing different construction materials, what other interventions can modify the surface of artificial structures to benefit biodiversity?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Interventions include creating textured surfaces (≤1 mm) on subtidal structures, which altered macroalgae and invertebrate community composition and in some cases increased richness and abundance when combined with environmentally-sensitive material, with mixed effects on algal and invertebrate abundances [3449]. Creating textured surfaces (≤1 mm) on intertidal structures showed mixed effects on species richness, did not increase algal abundance in two studies, and produced mixed or increased barnacle and mobile invertebrate abundances, with different textures supporting different abundances [3466]. Creating groove habitats (1–50 mm) on subtidal structures, alongside holes, pits and environmentally-sensitive material, altered community composition, increased species diversity, supported species absent from control surfaces, and had mixed effects on algal, invertebrate and fish abundances [3448]. Creating pit habitats (1–50 mm) on subtidal structures, with holes, grooves and environmentally-sensitive material, altered community composition, increased species diversity, supported species absent from control surfaces, and had mixed effects on algal, invertebrate and fish abundances [3455]. Creating long flexible habitats (>50 mm) on intertidal structures altered community composition, and the flexible habitats supported macroalgae and invertebrates absent from surfaces without them [3460]. Creating short flexible habitats (1–50 mm) on intertidal structures altered community composition, reduced overall species richness at low tide, showed mixed effects on algal and invertebrate abundances and mobile invertebrate richness, did not increase fish richness or abundance, and did not increase fish biting rates [3459].
summary_statements: Creating textured surfaces of 1 mm or less on subtidal structures is an intervention that altered macroalgae and invertebrate community composition.
When combined with environmentally-sensitive material, creating textured surfaces of 1 mm or less on subtidal structures in some cases increased species richness and abundance.
The creation of textured surfaces of 1 mm or less on subtidal structures had mixed effects on algal and invertebrate abundances.
Creating textured surfaces of 1 mm or less on intertidal structures showed mixed effects on species richness.
Creating textured surfaces of 1 mm or less on intertidal structures did not increase algal abundance in two studies.
The creation of textured surfaces of 1 mm or less on intertidal structures produced mixed or increased barnacle and mobile invertebrate abundances.
On intertidal structures, different textures supported different abundances of species.
Creating groove habitats between 1 and 50 mm on subtidal structures altered community composition.
The creation of groove habitats between 1 and 50 mm on subtidal structures increased species diversity.
Groove habitats on subtidal structures supported species that were absent from control surfaces.
Creating groove habitats between 1 and 50 mm on subtidal structures had mixed effects on algal, invertebrate and fish abundances.
Creating pit habitats between 1 and 50 mm on subtidal structures altered community composition.
The creation of pit habitats between 1 and 50 mm on subtidal structures increased species diversity.
Pit habitats on subtidal structures supported species that were absent from control surfaces.
Creating pit habitats between 1 and 50 mm on subtidal structures had mixed effects on algal, invertebrate and fish abundances.
Creating long flexible habitats greater than 50 mm on intertidal structures altered community composition.
Long flexible habitats on intertidal structures supported macroalgae and invertebrates that were absent from surfaces without these habitats.
Creating short flexible habitats between 1 and 50 mm on intertidal structures altered community composition.
The creation of short flexible habitats on intertidal structures reduced overall species richness at low tide.
Short flexible habitats on intertidal structures showed mixed effects on algal and invertebrate abundances and mobile invertebrate richness.
The creation of short flexible habitats on intertidal structures did not increase fish richness or abundance.
Creating short flexible habitats on intertidal structures did not increase fish biting rates.
